subject: Creativity
title: Fantasy World-Building: Creating Believable Impossible Places
description: A quick, practical guide to Fantasy World-Building: Creating Believable Impossible Places.

hook.text: Tolkien spent 12 years building Middle-earth's languages before writing a single chapter of The Lord of the Rings.

buildup.text: Great fantasy worlds follow internal logic. Magic has costs. Geography shapes culture. History explains conflict.

discovery.text: Brandon Sanderson's First Law: magic that solves problems must have clear rules. Mysterious magic creates wonder.

twist.text: The best world-building is invisible. Readers feel immersed without noticing the scaffolding beneath.

climax.text: Ursula K. Le Guin built alien cultures to critique real ones. World-building is never just escapism.

punchline.text: The best imaginary worlds feel more real than reality.

quiz.question: What is Sanderson's First Law of magic systems?
options: Problem-solving magic needs clear rules; mysterious magic creates wonder
All magic must have a cost
